overview: A high-performance, data-driven portfolio website designed to serve as a centralized content management system for my personal brand. Unlike typical static site generators, this application uses a custom JSON-based architecture to decouple data from the presentation layer, allowing for instant content updates without recompiling code. It serves as a living document of my skills, featuring a highly interactive UI that adapts to user preferences and device constraints.
problem: Static HTML portfolios are difficult to maintain; updating a single project often requires editing multiple HTML files, leading to code duplication and errors. Conversely, full-blown CMS solutions like WordPress are too heavy and bloated for a simple developer showcase. I needed a lightweight, custom solution that demonstrated full-stack capability while remaining performant, accessible, and easy to update via a simple data file.
solution: I built a Flask (Python) application that renders Jinja2 templates dynamically based on local JSON data stores. The frontend implements a sophisticated glassmorphism design system using raw CSS variables for easy theming. The architecture separates concerns strictly: data lives in JSON, logic in Python, and presentation in HTML/CSS. This allows me to add a new project by simply appending an object to a text file, without touching a single line of frontend code.
features: JSON-driven content management system (No database required)
Dynamic Routing System that generates pages from IDs
SMTP Email System with asynchronous processing
Responsive Glassmorphism UI using modern CSS Grid
Intersection Observer API for scroll-triggered animations
SEO-optimized meta tags generated dynamically per project

challenges.title: CSS Architecture
challenges.desc: Managing glassmorphism effects across light and dark modes required a complex system of CSS HSL variables. I had to calculate specific contrast ratios to ensure readability while maintaining the 'frosted glass' aesthetic on various background colors.

challenges.title: Asset Optimization
challenges.desc: To ensure a Lighthouse performance score of 95+, I implemented a custom lazy-loading strategy. Images are fetched with 'loading=lazy' and 'decoding=async', and heavy scripts are deferred until user interaction is detected.

challenges.title: State Persistence
challenges.desc: preventing the 'Flash of Incorrect Theme' (FOUC) on page load required injecting a blocking script in the head to check LocalStorage before the DOM painted.

challenges.title: Dynamic Navigation
challenges.desc: Building a 'Next/Previous Project' navigation system that automatically determines the correct linking order based on the JSON array index.

overview: FamilyConnect is a private social networking prototype designed to simulate the core architecture of platforms like Facebook, but optimized for close-knit family groups. It focuses on privacy, data sovereignty, and secure media sharing without the algorithmic noise of public networks. The platform allows family units to create private spaces where they can share milestones, photos, and updates without fear of data mining.
problem: Public social networks monetize user data and expose family memories to the public internet. Furthermore, their algorithms prioritize engagement over connection, often hiding important family updates. There was a clear need for a self-hostable, isolated environment where families could own their data and share updates securely.
solution: I developed a monolithic Flask application backed by a normalized MySQL database. The system implements strict Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) and uses server-side session management to ensure that only authenticated family members can access content. The architecture prioritizes data integrity and security, utilizing strong encryption for passwords and sanitization for all user inputs.
features: Secure Authentication using BCrypt password hashing
Relational Feed Algorithm based on time and relevance
Admin Dashboard for user management and content moderation
Nested Commenting System with unlimited depth
Real-time Flash messaging for user feedback

challenges.title: Database Normalization
challenges.desc: Designing a schema that efficiently links Users, Posts, and Comments (nested relationships) was critical. I had to carefully define Foreign Keys and indexing strategies to prevent N+1 query performance issues when loading the main feed.

challenges.title: Image Storage
challenges.desc: Allowing users to upload high-res family photos quickly filled up server storage. I implemented an image processing pipeline that resizes and compresses images to WebP format before saving them to disk.

challenges.title: Security Logic
challenges.desc: Implementing 'Row Level Security' logic in the application layer to ensure that a user could only delete or edit their own comments and posts, not those of others.

overview: Workplace is a collaborative task management hub designed specifically for academic teams. It solves the problem of fragmented communication by providing a single dashboard for tracking deadlines, sharing resources, and managing project milestones. Think of it as a simplified Trello or Asana, tailored for the specific needs of student groups.
problem: Student group projects often fail due to miscommunication across multiple channels like WhatsApp, Email, and Google Drive. Teams lacked a 'Single Source of Truth' for their project status, leading to missed deadlines and duplicated work.
solution: I built a lightweight project management tool using Flask and Bootstrap. It features a Kanban-style workflow (To Do, Doing, Done) and a centralized file repository system. The app distinguishes between 'Team Leads' (who can assign tasks) and 'Members' (who update status), enforcing a structured workflow.
features: Task State Machine (To-Do -> In Progress -> Done)
Team Member Invite System via Email
Visual Progress Bars for project completion

challenges.title: Route Protection
challenges.desc: Securing admin routes against unauthorized access was paramount. I wrote custom Python decorators (@admin_required) that inspect the session user's role before allowing the request to proceed.

challenges.title: File Handling
challenges.desc: Managing secure file uploads required sanitizing filenames to prevent directory traversal attacks and ensuring that files were served with the correct MIME types.

challenges.title: State Logic
challenges.desc: Designing the logic to prevent invalid state transitions (e.g., moving a task from 'Done' back to 'To-Do' without admin approval).

overview: A graphical implementation of the classic Tic Tac Toe game, featuring a custom-built AI opponent. This project served as a deep study in game state management, heuristic algorithms, and rendering graphics using Python's Turtle module. It goes beyond simple if-else logic to implement a reactive opponent.
problem: Building a Command Line Interface (CLI) game is simple, but rendering a responsive GUI and programming an opponent that actually 'blocks' user moves requires understanding game loops, coordinate geometry, and state evaluation.
solution: I wrote a custom rendering loop using Python Turtle to draw the board and pieces. The core technical highlight is the AI logic, which evaluates the board state after every turn. It identifies winning threats across all 8 axes (rows, columns, diagonals) and prioritizes blocking the player over making a random move.
features: Heuristic AI that blocks player wins
Smooth 60 FPS Game Loop using Turtle
Sound effects for moves and game over

challenges.title: Coordinate Mapping
challenges.desc: The hardest part was translating pixel-perfect mouse clicks on the canvas (e.g., x=150, y=200) to the logical 3x3 game matrix (row=0, col=2) to update the internal state correctly.

challenges.title: AI Decision Tree
challenges.desc: Writing the algorithm to check for 'almost wins' (2 out of 3 cells filled) efficiently without hardcoding every possible board combination.

challenges.title: Rendering Loop
challenges.desc: Ensuring the Turtle graphics window updated smoothly without flickering or freezing while the AI was 'thinking'.

overview: A comprehensive digital portal for the Computer Science department, developed to digitize the traditional notice board. It provides a CMS for faculty members to publish news and a responsive interface for students to access exam schedules, syllabus materials, and event announcements.
problem: Critical information about exams and seminars was often missed because it was only posted on a physical wooden board in the hallway. Students who weren't on campus missed updates, and faculty found it tedious to print and pin papers manually.
solution: I developed a dynamic website with a secure Admin Panel. Faculty members can log in to upload PDF notices and event details, which are immediately pushed to the student news feed. The frontend was built with mobile-first principles to ensure accessibility on student smartphones.

challenges.title: Legacy Browser Support
challenges.desc: The university lab computers were running outdated versions of Internet Explorer. I had to use Polyfills and careful CSS fallbacks to ensure the modern layout didn't break on legacy hardware.

challenges.title: File Organization
challenges.desc: Designing a folder structure on the server that separated public PDFs from private admin documents while keeping URLs clean and predictable.

overview: Watermark Studio is a desktop automation tool built to batch-process images. It allows photographers and content creators to apply transparent watermarks to hundreds of photos in seconds, preserving metadata and quality. It provides a graphical interface for what is usually a command-line task.
problem: Manually opening Photoshop to watermark 50+ event photos is tedious and time-consuming. Online tools often compress images, reduce quality, or have file limits. There was a need for a local, fast, and privacy-focused solution.
solution: I built a native GUI application using Python (Tkinter) and Pillow. It performs pixel-perfect alpha compositing to blend watermarks onto images in bulk. The tool includes controls for opacity, padding, and position, allowing for precise placement regardless of image orientation.
features: Support for JPG, PNG, and WEBP formats

challenges.title: Aspect Ratio Logic
challenges.desc: Ensuring the watermark stays proportional whether the target image is a 4K landscape or a 720p portrait required complex scaling math based on percentage rather than fixed pixels.

challenges.title: Memory Management
challenges.desc: Processing hundreds of high-res images could crash the script. I implemented a garbage collection strategy to clear memory buffers after each image was saved.

overview: A faithful recreation of the classic arcade Snake game. This project explores the fundamentals of game development, including the main game loop, collision detection algorithms, and real-time user input handling. It focuses on smooth mechanics and responsive controls.
problem: Understanding how software handles real-time user input and updates the screen state 60 times a second without lagging. Specifically, managing the data structure of a growing entity that moves across a discrete grid.
solution: I implemented the game engine using Python (Pygame). It uses a queue-based system (FIFO) to track the snake's body segments. Moving the snake involves adding a new head segment in the direction of travel and popping the tail segment, creating the illusion of movement.
features: Coordinate Queue System for body tracking

challenges.title: Input Latency (The Suicide Bug)
challenges.desc: If a player pressed 'Down' then 'Left' faster than one game tick, the snake would turn into itself and die immediately. I solved this by buffering input commands and processing only one direction change per frame.

challenges.title: Grid Alignment
challenges.desc: Ensuring the food spawned only on valid grid coordinates and never inside the snake's current body required a recursive checking algorithm.
